data.question: What is the difference between agile software development and traditional software development?
items: At the level of actual software development, there isn't a difference. Both produce code aimed at solving a problem
Traditional development focuses more on plans and process while agile focuses more on outcomes and value
Agile development focuses more on plans and process while traditional development focuses more on outcomes and value
Traditional development is much more disciplined than agile because of the distinct phases

data.question: Which of the following are benefits of using an Agile method?
data.explanation: D is correct, 2 and 7 are not benefits of any Agile method. In fact, it is very often the absence of clear requirements at the start of projects that drive many organizations to con-sider an Agile approach.

data.question: Improved efficiency and effectiveness
Continuous development
data.explanation: D is correct, 2 and 7 are not benefits of any Agile method. In fact, it is very often the absence of clear requirements at the start of projects that drive many organizations to con-sider an Agile approach.

data.question: Manage change and risk
data.explanation: B is correct. Many project managers schooled in traditional approaches have a difficult time with Agile because they have difficultly adopting the necessary Agile mindset.

data.question: Customer centric
data.explanation: C is correct. It is close to a Scrum Principle (Inspect and adapt).

data.question: Transparency
Team accountability
Clear requirements
items: All of the above
data.explanation: B is correct, Agile methods recommend team decision models.

data.question: What is one of the problems Agile methods seek to solve?
items: They don't solve problems, it only provides guidance
The pace of business change
Traditional project management totally fails when it comes to software development
Agile methods make it easier for traditional project managers to understand what is going on in each management stage of the project
data.explanation: B is correct. Many project managers schooled in traditional approaches have a difficult time with Agile because they have difficultly adopting the necessary Agile mindset.

data.question: Which of the following is NOT an Agile principle?
items: Working software is the measure of success
Collaboration
Inspect and adopt
Self-organizing teams
data.explanation: C is correct. It is close to a Scrum Principle (Inspect and adapt).

data.question: What is value-based prioritization?
items: The priority assigned to a requirement (or user story) by the Development Team
The priority assigned by the project manager
The priority assigned that represent value to the business of the capability or feature
The priority agreed by negotiation between the project manager and the development team

data.question: What is the difference between Agile approaches to projects and traditional project management?
items: When you net it out, there really isn't much difference
Agile methods adjust scope and hold cost and time fixed. Traditional methods hold scope fixed and adjust cost and time
Traditional methods adjust scope and hold cost and time fixed. Agile methods hold scope fixed and adjust cost and time
Agile approaches are much harder to do, which is why so few organizations consider using them

data.question: Which of the following is NOT a domain of Agile practice?
items: Adaptive planning
Individual decision models with full transparency
Agile tools and artifacts
Continuous improvement
data.explanation: B is correct, Agile methods recommend team decision models.

data.question: What is the difference in approach to improvement between Agile and tradition project management?
items: Agile iterations or stages are shorter so they are only applied at the start of each iteration or stage
There isn't any difference, both approaches recommend improvement
Agile models use continuous improvement to drive projects
Traditional project management and Agile both consider lessons learned

data.question: In the context of lean software development, what does "preserve value with less work," mean?
items: Identify who will use or benefit from the products produced by the product and then do what they require
Make sure the requisite meetings and artifacts are produced before the project starts to optimize efficiency
Make sure the project is viable before it starts to avoid waste
Do only what is necessary to deliver value, no more, no less

data.question: Why is the principle to amplify learning important?
items: Team members should have a thorough understanding regarding what the product or service should do
Team members need to understand not only what the outputs from the effort will do, but why the outcomes are important
The team is more intelligent than individual members
Amplified learning helps make the team brighter because there is the possibility to apply cross-functional skills
data.explanation: B is correct. While C and might be a universal truth, it's not specifically the purpose of the principle.

data.question: Why is it important to decide as late as possible?
items: Allows the scope of control to be closer to the scope of effect
That's just the Lean approach; the real issue isn't when decisions are made, but that they are made. Decide as late as possible makes sure decisions don't fall through the crack
Deciding later means the decisions are made with the best available information
Deciding later only applies to allowing the team to determine the highest value features

data.question: Which of the following is NOT an aspect of, "deliver as fast as possible?"
items: Stakeholders are required to be engaged rapidly so that value can be determined
Work-in-progress may have unknown defects
Shorter iteration allow more time for key decisions
Pull systems allow for just-in-time decision making
data.explanation: A is correct, the other answers are included aspects.

data.question: What is an aspect of a leader in lean? Leaders must be able to…
items: Make decisions
Align tools and processes with the needs of the business
Empower people and help them align with Lean and project goals
Take control

data.question: What types of integrity are included in lean?
items: Personal integrity and perceptual integrity
Project integrity and communication integrity
Perceptual integrity and conceptual integrity
System integrity and iteration integrity

data.question: See the whole means…?
items: Think in systems
Understand the end-to-end sequence of events
Use appropriate metrics and measurement
Avoid constraints because they make it impossible to focus on the real problem

data.question: Which of the following is a benefit of Lean Software Development?
items: There aren't any benefits that are specific to Lean
Lean focuses on core Agile principles with a particular focus on the elimination of waste
Lean is really a lightweight approach to Agile that is easier to follow than other methods
Lean isn't intended to be a stand-alone approach. Lean is about the identification of waste, it needs other approaches to do the work

data.question: Which of the following is a Kanban Principle?
items: Management at all levels
Accommodate change
Keep the current roles and responsibilities without change
Pursue incremental change
data.explanation: D is correct. While the principle to start with what you have now might appear to suggest C, the disqualifier is the phrase: without change.

data.question: What does the Kanban principle, "Start with what you do now," mean? If it differs from other Agile methods, how does it differ?
items: This Kanban principle helps you understand where you are now and how to improve it. It doesn't really differ from other Agile methods, they all focus on improving the current situation
If you don't do something, nothing will change; you have to get started. Other Agile approaches describe meetings, how to run them and roles
If you don't do something, nothing will change; you have to get started. It doesn't really differ from other Agile methods, they all focus on improving the current situation
This Kanban principle helps you understand where you are now and how to improve it. Other Agile approaches describe meetings, how to run them and roles

data.question: Which statement about Limit Work-in-process is true?
items: Get more done by doing less
Don't try to do too much at once, it's not healthy and makes it impossible to encourage acts of leadership
The limit only applies to adding something new; it does not apply to everything
New work is pushed into development only when there is the capability to accept it
data.explanation: This might not be obvious, but A is correct, but limiting work in process to the level of capacity of people to absorb new effort, there is less likelihood for the loss in productivity that comes from context switching. It also helps support a sustainable pace which allows people to continue to work at higher levels of productivity for longer periods of time.

data.question: Which of the following is NOT an aspect of, "Manage Flow?"
items: Manage flow integrates with "Start with what you do now" to accommodate the necessary project management controls and reports for the project manager
Manage flow provides a focus on incremental change
Manage flow helps recognize how change drives system improvement or degradation
Manage flow allows for work to be monitored, measured and reported
data.explanation: A is correct, the others ARE aspect of Manage Flow.

data.question: Why is it important to make policies explicit?
Avoids assumptions
data.explanation: D is correct. While the principle to start with what you have now might appear to suggest C, the disqualifier is the phrase: without change.

data.question: Facilitate collaboration and transparency
Leads to likelihood of consensus
items: 1 and 2
1 and 3
2 and 3
All of the above
data.explanation: This might not be obvious, but A is correct, but limiting work in process to the level of capacity of people to absorb new effort, there is less likelihood for the loss in productivity that comes from context switching. It also helps support a sustainable pace which allows people to continue to work at higher levels of productivity for longer periods of time.

data.question: Kanban recommends feedback loops for which of the following?
Work flow
data.explanation: D is correct. While the principle to start with what you have now might appear to suggest C, the disqualifier is the phrase: without change.

data.question: Demand analysis
Capacity planning
data.explanation: This might not be obvious, but A is correct, but limiting work in process to the level of capacity of people to absorb new effort, there is less likelihood for the loss in productivity that comes from context switching. It also helps support a sustainable pace which allows people to continue to work at higher levels of productivity for longer periods of time.

data.question: Existing metrics
items: 1 and 4 only
All of the above
data.explanation: A is correct, the others ARE aspect of Manage Flow.

data.question: Building shared understanding of work, flow, process and risk is an element of which Kanban practice?
items: Visualize
Limit WIP
Implement regular feedback loops
Improve collaboratively, evolve experimentally

data.question: Kaizen applies to which Kanban practice?
items: Visualize
Limit WIP
Implement regular feedback loops
Improve collaboratively, evolve experimentally
data.explanation: While you could argue that kaizen could apply to every Kanban practice, it is only specifically mentioned in the context of C, the correct answer.

data.question: Which of the following are benefits of using Scrum?
Adaptability
Continuous development
Sustainable pace
data.explanation: C is correct. Inspect and adapt are part of Empirical Process Control; adopt isn't considered.

data.question: Customer centric
data.explanation: While the priority assigned by the Product Owner should reflect business value, that isn't the answer to the question. The correct answer is C.

data.question: High Velocity
Motivation
Clear requirements
items: All of the above
data.explanation: B is correct; release planning occurs in the Initiate phase.

data.question: How does the Scrum Guidance Body contribute to scalability?
items: It doesn't, it only provides documentation and guidance
The SGB determine how Scrum scales within the organization
The SGB recommends when to hold various meetings that are part of Scrum
The SGB documents the rules for scalability

data.question: Which of the following is NOT a Scrum principle?
items: Iterative Development
Collaboration
Inspect and adopt
Self-organizing teams
data.explanation: C is correct. Inspect and adapt are part of Empirical Process Control; adopt isn't considered.

data.question: What is value-based prioritization?
items: The priority assigned to a user story by the Development Team
The priority assigned by the Product Owner
The priority assigned that represents business value
The priority agreed by negotiation between the Product Owner and the Development Team
data.explanation: While the priority assigned by the Product Owner should reflect business value, that isn't the answer to the question. The correct answer is C.

data.question: A business case documents the business justification for the Scrum project. What else does the business case provide?
Basis for project scope
Estimated costs
Options
data.explanation: C is correct. Inspect and adapt are part of Empirical Process Control; adopt isn't considered.

data.question: Risks
items: 1 and 2
2 and 3
1 and 4
All of the above
data.explanation: While the priority assigned by the Product Owner should reflect business value, that isn't the answer to the question. The correct answer is C.

data.question: What is true of the two aspects of the Review & Retrospect phase?
items: The Review focuses on lessons learned, the Retrospect focuses on customer value
The Review focuses on customer value; the Retrospect focuses on lessons learned
The Review focuses on process improvement; the Retrospect focuses on demonstration, inspect and adapt
The Review focuses on demonstration, inspect and adapt; the Retrospect focuses on process improvement

data.question: Which of the following are NOT considered as part of the Plan and Estimate phase?
items: Create the Sprint Backlog
Plan the Release
Create User Stories
Estimate tasks
data.explanation: B is correct; release planning occurs in the Initiate phase.

data.question: What is true about a time-box in Scrum?
It is a fixed period of time for each development
It is a fixed period of time for meetings
It is the basis of iterative and incremental delivery
items: 1 and 2
2 and 3
1 and 3
All of the above
data.explanation: C is correct. Inspect and adapt are part of Empirical Process Control; adopt isn't considered.

data.question: Which XP value is similar to a Lean Software Development practice?
items: YAGNI
Courage
Communication
Technical excellence
data.explanation: A is correct. It is share a similar intent to the Eliminate Waste practice that is part of Lean.

data.question: Which of the following are included in XP planning?
data.explanation: C is correct. Deployment is planned at a later time.

data.question: Write user stories
data.explanation: A is correct. It is share a similar intent to the Eliminate Waste practice that is part of Lean.

data.question: Plan release and deployment
data.explanation: C is correct. Deployment is planned at a later time.

data.question: Divide the project into iterations
items: 1 and 2
2 and 3
1 and 3
All of the above

data.question: Which of the following are NOT included as part of managing in XP?
Dedicated, open workspaces
data.explanation: A is correct. It is share a similar intent to the Eliminate Waste practice that is part of Lean.

data.question: Demonstrate done user stories
data.explanation: C is correct. Deployment is planned at a later time.

data.question: Establish a sustainable pace
Move people between projects
Fix it when it breaks
items: 1 and 3
2 and 4

data.question: What is a system metaphor in XP?
items: A set of user stories that serve as abstractions to map part of the system
Basis for naming workspaces
A representation of a story that everyone can tell about how the system works
Used to gain knowledge necessary to reduce risk

data.question: What is the purpose for a spike in XP?
items: Like a point of sale that "spikes" orders once completed, the spike holds completed stories
It serves as an accumulation point for lessons learned
It is a way to prevent feature creep
Special type of story used for exploration

data.question: Which of the following are included as part of Coding in XP?
Customer is always available
data.explanation: A is correct. It is share a similar intent to the Eliminate Waste practice that is part of Lean.

data.question: Code the unit test first
data.explanation: C is correct. Deployment is planned at a later time.

data.question: Production code is pair-programmed
Integrate frequently
Establish a dedicate integration computer (or server)
items: All of the above

data.question: Which statement about testing in XP is true?
data.explanation: Code must pass all unit tests before release. B is correct.

data.question: Test must be written before any attempt is made to write the code
data.explanation: A is correct. It is share a similar intent to the Eliminate Waste practice that is part of Lean.

data.question: Code must pass most unit tests before release
data.explanation: C is correct. Deployment is planned at a later time.

data.question: Tests are created in response to the discovery of bugs and added to the test-base
items: 1 and 2
1 and 3
2 and 3
All of the above

data.question: Which statements apply to the planning game in XP?
It is the main planning process in XP
data.explanation: A is correct. It is share a similar intent to the Eliminate Waste practice that is part of Lean.

data.question: It is divided into two parts (Release / deployment planning and iteration planning)
data.explanation: C is correct. Deployment is planned at a later time.

data.question: It starts new iterations when new work is added
It is "played" by both customer and developers
It is a way for XP to accommodate change
items: All of the above
2 and 4

data.question: Which of the following are principles of DSDM?
Active user involvement is imperative
Focus on the business need
Iterative and incremental development
Collaborative and cooperative approach
Deliver on time
Baseline requirements at a high level
items: All of the above

data.question: The best statement of the purpose for the pre-project phase of DSDM is…?
items: Make sure the project is feasible with a valid business purpose and appropriate foundation
Explore the various aspects of the project, including alternatives
Determine the expected business value
Set up the project for success and formalizes a proposal with an appropriate business value

data.question: Which of the following is the correct interpretation of MoSCoW rules?
Must have or it won't meet minimal functionality
Must have or scrap the project
It's important and the product should have it, but if you can't get to it that's OK
The product should have, figure out a way to fit it in.
Nice, but don't worry about it
Nice to have if you can get to it, without comprising something more important
Won't have, period
Won't have in this iteration
Which of the following correctly associates a description with a DSDM role?
items: Business Sponsor is a senior level role engaged in the project
Project Manager actively engage in the project interpreting questions and keeping every-one on task
Technical Coordinator is the project architect
Business Ambassador is the most senior business role on the project

data.question: Which of the following statements are true?
DSDM was designed to work with traditional project management
The project manager role in DSDM is only necessary if DSDM is integrated into traditional project management
items: 1 is true
2 is true
Both are true
Neither statement is true

data.question: Which statement about the Crystal family is true?
items: Crystal Clear is applied every time there are 6 or fewer people involved
The primary determinant for darker colors (anything not "Clear) is the anticipated duration and complexity of the effort
Crystal Maroon requires integration with traditional project management because the project is so large and complex
The Crystal family works because each project is unique and the Crystal family is designed to scale to different project types

data.question: Which statements about the Crystal Principles are true?
Crystal use time-boxing when it's appropriate
These 3 are key, the others can be applied as needed: Frequent delivery, close communication, personal safety
Crystal team members aren't expected to know everything about the development domain, so access to experts is required for every Crystal project
items: 1 and 2
1 and 3
2 and 3
None of the above

data.question: Which of the following are Feature Driven Development best practices?
Domain object modeling
Develop by feature
Individual class ownership
Inspections
Configuration management
Regular builds
Information radiators
items: All of the above
